description: From Medieval Latin liquidatus (“liquid, clear”), past participle of liquidare. The sense “to kill, do away with” is a semantic loan from Russian ликвиди́ровать (likvidírovatʹ), ultimately from Latin liquidus.

verbs.description: liquidate (third-person singular simple present liquidates, present participle liquidating, simple past and past participle liquidated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To settle (a debt) by paying the outstanding amount.
examples: Friburg was ceded to Zurich by Sigismund to liquidate a debt of a thousand florins.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To settle the affairs of (a company), by using its assets to pay its debts.
(transitive) To convert (assets) into cash; to redeem.
(law, transitive) To determine by agreement or by litigation the precise amount of (indebtedness); to make the amount of (a debt) clear and certain.
examples: A debt or demand is liquidated whenever the amount due is agreed on by the parties, or fixed by the operation of law.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To make clear and intelligible.
examples: Time only can liquidate the meaning of all parts of a compound system.
